title: Document associativity patterns under local operations
description: PRD ref: C5. Document that creating an anyon at site j or applying local Hamiltonian terms produces states in non-standard associativity patterns. F-moves required to restore canonical form. For sVec, F=1 so this is trivial; for Fibonacci, nontrivial. Acceptance: (1) Explicit worked examples, (2) Algorithm for F-move restoration documented, (3) Cost analysis for different categories.

title: CRITICAL: Clarify hilbert_space.md <-> operators.md circular dependency
description:
Issue: Dependency structure unclear between hilbert_space.md and operators.md.

Current metadata:
- hilbert_space.md refs-out: [operators.md, hamiltonian_v0.md]
- operators.md refs-in: [hilbert_space.md, ...]

But conceptual dependency is two-way:
- Hilbert space $\mathcal{H}$ defined in hilbert_space.md
- Operators decompose in morphism space sums (Definition 4.3.2)
- But operators act on Hilbert space, so they need Hilbert space as target

Problem: Which is logically prior?

Resolution:
1. Make clear that hilbert_space.md Definition 4.2 defines $\mathcal{H}$ (required for operators)
2. Define basic operator concept (Definition 4.3.1) without reference to Hilbert space structure
3. Then show operators act on Hilbert space (Definition 4.3.2-4.3.6)
4. Fix metadata to reflect: hilbert_space โ operators (unidirectional dependency)

Files: hilbert_space.md, operators.md, metadata in front matter

Estimate: Medium (1 day)

title: CRITICAL: Clarify Definition 4.3.2 (operator as morphism sum) - undefined quantification
description:
Issue: operators.md Definition 4.3.2 (line 23-25) states:

๐ โ โ_{A,B} Mor(A, B)
where A, B range over tensor products of ๐, X_1, ..., X_{d-1}.

Undefined:
- What is the range exactly? All finite tensor products?
- Is the direct sum finite or infinite?
- Are we including all possible objects of the category?

Current formulation is informal and incomplete.

Fix: Write formally:
๐ โ โ_{k_A, k_B โ โ, i_j, i'_k โ {0,...,d-1}} Mor(X_{i_1} โ ยทยทยท โ X_{i_{k_A}}, X_{i'_1} โ ยทยทยท โ X_{i'_{k_B}})

Add assumption: 'We consider finite tensor products (finite k_A, k_B).'

Files: operators.md Definition 4.3.2

Estimate: Low (1 hour)

title: Document collision vs passing distinction
description: PRD ref: C4. Document that Mor(X โ Y, Y โ X) without braiding represents collision/scattering processes (fuse to intermediate Z, then dissociate), NOT free passage. Free passage requires braiding for unitary ordering identification. Scattering amplitudes depend on fusion channels. Acceptance: (1) Physical interpretation documented, (2) Hamiltonian terms correctly classified, (3) Examples for Fibonacci and sVec.

title: CRITICAL: De-duplicate morphism space definitions (fusion_category.md vs morphism_spaces.md)
description:
Issue: Morphism spaces are defined twice:
1. fusion_category.md line 31 (inline, within fusion category discussion)
2. morphism_spaces.md Definition 3.3 (standalone)
3. hilbert_space.md Definition 4.2.1 (duplicate again)

Problem: Three definitions of the same concept violate DRY principle. Code will diverge.

Solution: Create single canonical definition in morphism_spaces.md.
- Remove Definition 4.2.1 from hilbert_space.md
- Replace with cross-reference to morphism_spaces.md Definition 3.1.3
- Update fusion_category.md to reference (not redefine)

Files: fusion_category.md, morphism_spaces.md, hilbert_space.md, all assumption tables

Estimate: Medium effort (1 day)

title: Explicit treatment of associativity patterns in morphism spaces
description:
Planning ref: Critical/Epic for ยง3.1 onwards.

ISSUE: The morphism spaces as abstract vector spaces are isomorphic regardless of bracketing (Mac Lane coherence). However, when we work with concrete operators and states, we need to commit to a specific associativity pattern.

Two approaches:
1. **Fusion trees**: Fix a canonical binary bracketing and label internal edges
2. **Explicit tensor bracketing**: Write out parentheses explicitly in tensor products

REQUIREMENT: This distinction must be explicitly pointed out from the introduction of fusion categories (ยง3.1) onward, and carried through consistently in:
- Definition of morphism spaces (ยง3.1.3)
- F-symbols and associators (ยง3.1.4)
- Hilbert space construction (ยง4.2)
- Operator definitions (ยง4.3)

ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA:
1. Early warning in fusion category section about this subtlety
2. Clear statement of which convention we adopt (or how we handle both)
3. Consistent notation throughout all subsequent sections
4. Examples showing the difference in concrete calculations

IMPACT: Affects all sections from ยง3.1 onward. This is a foundational issue that must be resolved before proceeding with operator constructions.

title: CRITICAL: Renumber all definitions to match research_plan.md hierarchy
description:
Review code issue: Definition numbering is inconsistent.

Currently:
- fusion_ring.md: Definition 3.1
- fusion_category.md: Definitions 3.2, 3.3, 3.4, 3.5, 3.6
- morphism_spaces.md: Definitions 3.3, 3.4
- config_space.md: Definitions 4.1.1-4.1.4
- hilbert_space.md: Definitions 4.2.1-4.2.6

Problem: Definitions are numbered sequentially within each file, but research_plan.md defines hierarchy as:
- ยง3.1: Fusion Rings and Categories (substeps 3.1.1-3.1.8)
- ยง3.2: Fock Space (3.2.1-3.2.4)
- ยง3.3: QM Lattice (3.3.1-3.3.12)
- ยง3.4: Lattice Geometry (3.4.1-3.4.10)
- ยง3.5: Diagrammatic Calculus (3.5.1-3.5.6)
- ยง4.1-4.5: Hilbert Space sections
- etc.

Action: Renumber all definitions globally to match this structure. Update symbols.yaml and all cross-references.
File impact: All docs in docs/
Estimate: High effort (1 week)

title: Document F-moves vs R-moves distinction
description: PRD ref: C2. Document the fundamental distinction between F-moves and R-moves. F-moves: unitary transforms between associativity patterns (parenthesisations) for same particle ordering. R-moves: unitary identification between different particle orderings. These are independent structures. Acceptance: (1) Clear documentation with examples, (2) Diagrams showing the difference, (3) Code API reflects this distinction.

title: MEDIUM: Fix metadata inconsistencies - refs-in/refs-out declarations
description:
Issue: Several documents have misleading or incorrect refs-in/refs-out metadata:

Examples:
1. _overview.md claims refs-out: [fusion_category.md, hilbert_space.md, ...] 
   But none of those documents cite _overview.md. Metadata is aspirational.

2. hilbert_space.md claims refs-out: [operators.md, hamiltonian_v0.md]
   But content doesn't explicitly reference operators or hamiltonian - it's assumed as usage.

3. Transitive dependencies not visible:
   hilbert_space โ operators โ hamiltonian_v0 โ hamiltonian_v1
   Only direct links shown, obscuring full dependency chain.

Action:
1. Review all front-matter metadata for accuracy
2. Remove refs-out that aren't actually used in document
3. Consider adding a tool to generate dependency graphs (optional, for docs tooling)
4. Document metadata guidelines: Only list documents that are actually cited/referenced

Files: All docs with front matter
Estimate: Medium (1 day)

Acceptance: (1) Documentation updated, (2) Hamiltonian construction reflects this, (3) No conflation of fusion with braiding in codebase.

- List supported categories: Fibonacci, Ising, Z_N (with parameters), sVec (fermionic)
- For each, provide:

title: MEDIUM: Clarify Definition 5.1.5 (hamiltonian_v0.md) - undefined 'nontrivial' concept
description:
Issue: hamiltonian_v0.md Definition 5.1.5 (line 61-69) mentions 'equal numbers of nontrivial (non-vacuum) factors'.

Undefined: What is nontrivial?

Implicit definition from context: nontrivial = non-vacuum = not X_0 = not ๐

Problem: Not formally stated. Should reference Definition 5.1.1 (Number operator / vacuum concept).

Fix:
1. Add to symbols.yaml: 'nontrivial object: X_i โ ๐ = X_0'
2. In Definition 5.1.5, replace parenthetical with explicit reference: '(as defined in Definition 5.1.1: vacuum = X_0 = ๐)'
3. Rewrite equation to be unambiguous:

h_j โ โ_{A,B: n(A)=n(B)} Mor(A, B)

where n(A) := count of nontrivial factors in tensor product A, i.e., |{i: a_i โ 0}| if A = X_{a_1} โ ... โ X_{a_k}.

Files: hamiltonian_v0.md, symbols.yaml

Estimate: Low (2 hours)

title: MEDIUM: Fix notation ambiguity - symbol N overloaded (3 meanings)
description:
Issue: Symbol N used for three different concepts:
1. Particle number: ๐ฝ_N (N-anyon sector), \hat{N} (number operator)
2. Fusion multiplicity: N_{ab}^c (fusion coefficient)
3. Ambiguous context:sometimes number operator \hat{N}, sometimes just subscript N

While technically disambiguated by context/notation, visually confusing.

Example: 'N-anyon sector $\mathcal{H}_N$ with fusion multiplicity {ab}^c$'
Reader must parse two different N meanings in one sentence.

Action:
Option A: Rename particle number โ n_p in sectors, so โ_{n_p}
Option B: Keep current but enhance notation (e.g., N^{(p)} for particle number)
Option C: Document clearly in symbols.yaml and early chapters

Recommended: Option A (clearest)

Files: All documents, symbols.yaml, symbols.md

Estimate: High (1 day - global rename)

title: Fix undefined MobileAnyonHilbert in MobileAnyons/operators.jl
description: Validation failed with UndefVarError: MobileAnyonHilbert. This might be due to the Combinatorics failure in hilbert.jl or a missing import. Planning ref: Maintenance. Acceptance: operators.jl loads without error.

title: CRITICAL: Define 'simple object' formally (missing foundational definition)
description:
Issue: Multiple documents use 'simple object' (fusion_ring.md, fusion_category.md, morphism_spaces.md) without formal definition.

Current approach: Informal use, assuming reader knows definition from external sources.

Problem: For self-contained publication, must include rigorous definition.

Action: Add to ยง3.1 (or new ยง3.0) formal definition:

**Definition 3.1.0** (Simple object). Let C be a fusion category over field k. An object X โ C is *simple* if:
- X โ 0 (nonzero)
- X = Y โ Z implies Y = 0 or Z = 0 (indecomposable)
- End(X) โ k (Schur's lemma: only scalar endomorphisms)

Consequence: By semisimplicity, every object decomposes as finite direct sum of simples.

Files: fusion_ring.md (or new ยง3.0), symbols.yaml

Estimate: Low (2 hours)

title: Inconsistency in docs/config_space.md: Definition 4.1.1 (x_j in Lambda)
description: Definition 4.1.1 in `docs/config_space.md` states that anyon positions x_j belong to Lambda^N. However, Lambda is defined as a set of dimensionless site indices (0 to n-1) in Assumption A4.1.2, while elsewhere x_j are referred to as physical positions with units of length (e.g., in ยง4.1.3, which defines x_j = epsilon * j). This creates an inconsistency. The definition needs to be clarified to distinguish between site indices and physical positions, or Lambda must be consistently defined. Planning ref: ยง4.1.1. Acceptance: Definition 4.1.1 is mathematically consistent with other definitions of lattice sites, physical positions, and Lambda.

title: Document braiding requirement for particle ordering identification
description: PRD ref: C1. Document and verify that braiding (R-symbols) is required to unitarily identify morphism spaces for different particle orderings. Without braiding, Mor(1, X_i1 โ ... โ X_iN) for different position orderings have no canonical isomorphism. Acceptance: (1) Mathematical proof/justification documented, (2) Implications for non-braided models clarified, (3) Code comments updated where relevant.

title: Update docs/hilbert_space.md code snippets for TensorCategories
description: Planning ref: TC-REFACTOR-012. LOW PRIORITY. Update Julia code snippets in docs/hilbert_space.md. Update AnyonBasisState, MobileAnyonHilbert, build_basis_Nc examples to use TensorCategories types. Depends on TC-REFACTOR-006.

title: CRITICAL: Formalize F-symbol and R-symbol index notation
description:
Issue: F-symbols and R-symbols used in fusion_category.md without clear definition of indices.

Line 63-67 (Definition 3.3):
_{e, \alpha, \beta}^{f, \mu, \nu}$

Undefined:
- What is e? (answer: intermediate fusion channel, i โ {0,...,d-1})
- What is f? (same)
- What are ฮฑ, ฮฒ, ฮผ, ฮฝ? (multiplicity indices)

Line 75 (Pentagon equation):
โ_{k} (F_{a,b,c}^k)_e^l ... (F_{b,c,d}^p)_k^n = ...

Undefined: Are e, l, m, n object indices or multiplicity indices?

Action: Create subsection ยง3.5.5a: 'F-Symbol and R-Symbol Index Structure'
- Define intermediate channels: e, f, ... โ {0, 1, ..., d-1}
- Define multiplicity indices: ฮฑ, ฮฒ, ฮผ, ฮฝ โ {1, ..., N_{ab}^c}
- Rewrite pentagon and hexagon equations with full, unambiguous notation

Estimate: Medium effort (2-3 days)
close_reason: Formalized F/R-symbol index notation in ยง3.5.4a of diagrammatic_calculus.md. Updated fusion_category.md Definitions 3.1.4-3.1.7 with explicit index structure, clearer pentagon/hexagon equations, and cross-references.

title: MEDIUM: Standardize morphism notation - use Mor consistently (not Hom)
description:
Issue: AGENTS.md (line 391) specifies: Use \mathrm{Mor}(A, B) for morphisms (not \mathrm{Hom}).

Current usage:
- ~70% of documents use \mathrm{Mor}: โ Correct
- morphism_spaces.md Definition 3.3 line 23: \mathrm{Hom}_{\mathcal{C}}(A, B) โ Violates standard
- Some Julia comments use Hom in prose โ

Action: Global search-replace:
1. morphism_spaces.md: Change \mathrm{Hom} โ \mathrm{Mor}
2. All documents: Audit and standardize
3. Update symbols.yaml to reflect Mor standard

Files: morphism_spaces.md (primary), all docs (audit)

Estimate: Low (2 hours)
